Disclaimer 1: Product received for free
Disclaimer 2: I bought a copy for a friend so I could pay for this game as it is worth it. 

Void Destroyer is a unique game, it feels a bit like a space version of Mount & Blade meets Homeworld meets Battlezone meets original Void Destroyer. 

Essentially it is an open world sandbox where you start out in a small fighter and then it is up to you to do what you want.  You can fight, do missions, trade, mine, pirate, steal, wage wars or simply take over the system.  More than likely you will eventually end up doing a bit of most of those, some you will do yourself the rest you might get your AI minion fleets to do for you. 

What I love about this game is how it changes as you play.  Your experience during the first few hours as you do low paying jobs, struggling to earn enough credits to upgrade the rust bucket you have been given is very different from later on, where you wil go on to start commanding larger ships like corvettes, frigates and eventually destroyers. 

From flying your own trader to owning a fleet of trade ships and escorts, directing mining fleets and perhaps, even building an armada large enough to capture one of the space stations out there.  Once you do this the game again changes as you now have the ability to not only buy ships but build them and you have now transformed into a faction.  How far does your ambition go....?

Gameplay wise you are able to fly ANY ship in the game, from the lowliest drone fighter to the largest behemoth cruisers.  You have own many ships and jump between them as you see fit.  You can have them form their own mining or trade fleets to go and earn you money and resources, assign them to protect your assets or have them join you.  

There are a great many ships to choose from, tugs, a large number of light, medium & heavy fighters, corvettes, frigates, destroyers & cruisers and all armed with various deadly weaponry from turrets to missiles to beam weapons.  

Currently my fav is an Apollo Class light corvette that is pretty much my own personal Millenium Falcon, fast, agile and punches above her weight.  While I have pretty much upraded to a heavy beam frigate now as my ambitions sore, I will always fondly remember that ship. And yes you can name all of them :)

Those that join you, you are able to control via a tactical RTS style command system or in cockpit via simple Wingmen commands.  This allows to give complex instructions to your fleet and if you wish can play out entire confrontations like an RTS if you do not feel like taking to the cockpit. 

This is an EA game so there will be bugs, crashes, features to be implemented etc but it is a very flesh out game at this time and you can get many hours of enjoyment already. 

The developer is VERY responsive and it is not uncommon to report a bug and have him release a patch/bugfix within a day or two once he figures out what is causing it.  As such the EA user base here is very important to highlight not only bugs but features that either work well or could use improvement. 

If you like space, strategy or flying then this could be a game for you.

[h1]Start with nothing, build an empire. [/h1]

Void Destroyer 2 is a space sandbox game (and the sequel to Void Destroyer) developed by Iteration 11, a one-man dev ‘team’. In Void Destroyer 2 (VD2) you start with nothing, in fact you start as nothing. Confused and disoriented you wake up in a small, fighter class with two men talking you through how to fly your ship, it acts as an introduction to the premise of the game as well as a tutorial. After completing this fairly short but useful tutorial section, you’re free to explore the sandbox doing as you please (within the game’s limitations of course). 

Getting around in VD2 requires the use of VD2’s ‘Overworld View’, it’s pretty similar to how the Mount & Blade games work. You have an overview of the whole map and you move around between spaceports and other points of interest using it. The reason you’ll want to use it is because Overworld View has Time Compression, in other words you’ll get around much quicker than just flying there normally. The Overworld View displays everything from ships (different classes of ships have different icons) to asteroid fields and of course it also displays all the different spaceports. The Overview View is only available if you’re a set distance away from certain objects, the distance away you need to be is usually related to the size of the object or how dangerous it is, for example a cleared out mine-field only requires you to be 1000 units away whereas you have to be 10,000 units away from hostile ships before you can enter Overworld View. You’re also pulled out of Overworld View when you get too close to an object.

Outside of Overworld View most of your time will be spent actually controlling your ship (there’s also a tactical view which can be used to control your fleet). VD 2’s controls are good and all the ship handling felt good to me. There’s also a good amount of difference in handling between the different ships I’ve flown so far. How well a ship can maneuver during flight depends on how fast you’re going, your ship’s cruise speed or lower is the optimum speed to turn at as the correction rockets are able to manage your momentum in different directions so you keep going in the direction you’re actually facing. You can of course go faster than your cruise speed (as well as turn off auto-correction) but generally you’ll only want to do that if you’re trying to quickly leave or get to an area. 

As with most space sandbox games, there are three main ways of earning money in VD2: trading, mining & completing jobs picked up from spaceports. From what I’ve seen so far, trading is the best way to earn large amounts of reasonably quickly (especially if you have fleet or hired ships, more on those later). Mining is fairly self-explanatory, I’ve never been a fan of mining in space sandboxes so I haven’t messed around with it too much though there are ways of having ships automatically mine for you. As for the jobs, there’s currently a decent variety of jobs available to you, ranging from simple courier jobs to escort missions and bounty hunting. Each spaceport offers different jobs to you, some of the jobs will require that you use a faction ship. Completing jobs (of a certain difficulty, the level of difficulty required depends on what your level already is) will increase your relationship with the faction. Some ships available to buy at spaceports require a certain faction level before you can buy them.

The main idea of the game is that you start with next to nothing and as you progress you become more powerful. You do this in two ways. The first, and most obvious way, is by purchasing increasingly better ships when the money becomes available to you. The other way is to purchase new ships (or use older ships you’ve upgraded out of) to create a personal fleet of ships, as it stands there is no maximum fleet capacity or any upkeep costs. If you can’t afford to buy ships but need some backup or extra cargo capacity, you can also hire ships. Hiring ships is pretty cheap right now and the way it works is that you pay a set fee for each ship you have hired (you can hire a maximum of three) each time you dock at a spaceport. Each spaceport has certain ships which are available for you to hire and you may not be able to find what you’re looking for at each spaceport. 

As you’d expect with an Early Access games, there are some bugs. I’ve had a few crashes so far as well as some minor bugs where my ship spins out of control when colliding with something or having my ship change positions randomly when trying to enter Overworld View while targeting a moving object such as debris. There have also been some issues with the way the achievements have been set up but chaosavy (the dev’s Steam name) has been working on fixing that. Speaking of chaosavy, he’s super active in the Steam forums (in fact posting in the forum is the easiest way to get a hold of him) which is great to see, especially with an Early Access game.

My main issue with the game as it stands is that the trading side of things feels a bit unbalanced. When I started trading I had roughly 60,000 credits and through hiring ships and after figuring out a good trade route I was sitting on 600,000 credits. It took me an hour to get to that point. I don’t want it to be like it is in Elite Dangerous where you have to grind for tens of hours to afford what you want but I feel like the game would definitely benefit from it taking a tad longer to get the best ships. Alternatively, trading could be more difficult by having groups of wandering pirates who might attack you while you’re travelling. If this is already in the game, then I didn’t see any of them during said hour so I was able to go without upgrading my very basic ship.

Furthermore, VD 2 felt a little bare to me in some areas. Not necessarily lacking content (though more job variety would be welcome) but it just didn’t feel like a lived in game-world at some points. For example, when travelling close to spaceports I never saw any ships coming in or out of the spaceports. It’s a relatively small detail, and at this stage it’s definitely not a priority, but I would like to see it addressed at some point down the line. Another improvement in this department would be more ships 

[h1]Verdict [/h1]

Void Destroyer 2 is off to a good start, it isn’t without issues and it can feel bare at times but it's still a very enjoyable edition to the space sandbox genre. It has a long way to go but due to how hard chaosavy/Iteration 11 has been working even since release to fix things and improve the game I’m confident that a good final product will be delivered.
